raw_text:
UK Directors Guild nominees named
 
 Martin Scorsese and Clint Eastwood are among the nominees for the top prize at the Directors Guild of Great Britain awards, now in their second year.
 
 The Oscar rivals will compete for the international film prize at the ceremony, to be held at the Curzon Mayfair cinema in London on 20 March. Other nominees include Bill Condon for Kinsey and Michel Gondry for Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. Mike Leigh's Vera Drake is among the nominees for best British film. The awards will see Eastwood and Scorsese once again competing for the directing prize, following last weekend's Oscars. Clint Eastwood won best director for Million Dollar Baby, beating Scorsese who was nominated for a fifth time for the Howard Hughes biopic The Aviator. Mike Leigh will compete for the British film prize with Shane Meadows for Dead Man's Shoes, Roger Michell For Enduring Love and My Summer Of Love director Pawel Pawlikowski.
 
 Nominees for best foreign film include Spain's Pedro Almodovar for Bad Education and Hong Kong director Wong Kar-Wai for 2046. In the TV categories, comedy series Early Doors and The Alan Clark Diaries will compete for the best directing award for a 30-minute television show, while the directors of Shameless, Hustle and Bodies are all nominated for the 60-minute television prize. The directors of Omagh and Sex Traffic are among the nominees for a television movie or mini-series. American Beauty's Sam Mendes will receive a lifetime achievement award for his work in film and theatre, while theatre director Simon McBurney will be given an award for outstanding directorial achievement.
llama3.2:1b:
UK Directors Guild nominees:

* Martin Scorsese (Howard Hughes biopic)
* Clint Eastwood (Million Dollar Baby)
* Bill Condon (Kinsey)
* Michel Gondry (Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind)
* Mike Leigh (Vera Drake)
* Shane Meadows (Dead Man's Shoes)
* Roger Michell (Enduring Love)

International film nominees:

* Pedro Almodovar (Bad Education)
* Wong Kar-Wai (2046)

British film nominees:

* Vera Drake
* Dead Man's Shoes

Television categories:

* Best 30-minute television show: Early Doors, The Alan Clark Diaries
* TV movie or mini-series:
  - Omagh
  - Sex Traffic
llama3.2:3b: UK Directors Guild nominees include Martin Scorsese and Clint Eastwood for international film, Bill Condon for Kinsey and Michel Gondry for Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. Mike Leigh's Vera Drake is nominated for best British film against Shane Meadows, Roger Michell, and Pawel Pawlikowski. Nominees for foreign film include Pedro Almodovar and Wong Kar-Wai, with American Beauty's Sam Mendes receiving a lifetime achievement award.

Other nominees include Bill Condon, Michel Gondry, Mike Leigh, Pedro Almodovar, and Wong Kar-Wai.  The awards ceremony will be held on March 20th at the Curzon Mayfair cinema in London.  Mike Leigh and Shane Meadows are competing for the best British film award.

Other British nominees include: Mike Leigh, Vera Drake, Bill Condon, Pedro Almodovar, Wong Kar-Wai, Michael J. Fox, Andy Serkis, Alan Ball, Sam Mendes, Simon McBurney.

Other nominees include Bill Condon for Kinsey and Michel Gondry for Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. The competition also features Pedro Almodovar for Bad Education, Wong Kar-Wai for 2046, and Shane Meadows for Dead Man's Shoes.

The Directors Guild Awards are being held at the Curzon Mayfair cinema in London on March 20, featuring nominees for Best Director (Martin Scorsese, Clint Eastwood), Best Picture (Bill Condon, Michel Gondry), and Best British Film (Mike Leigh). The awards will also include a Lifetime Achievement award. Key contestants: Pedro Almodovar (Best Foreign Film) and Wong Kar-Wai (Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind), as well as contestants in TV categories for Bestdir, 30-minute TV show, and 60-minute TV prize.
tinyllama:1.1b: UK Director's Guild nominates Martin Scorsese and Clint Eastwood as directors for the top prize at the awards ceremony, to compete against other nominees such as Bill Condon for Kinsey, Michel Gondry for "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," Mike Leigh for Vera Drake, and Paweł Pawlikowski for Dead Man's Shoes. Eastwood and Scorsese are both competing for the Director's Guild award for best director, while Pedro Almodóvar is nominated for Bad Education and Woong Kar-wai is up for 2046 in the foreign film category. The Directors Guild of Great Britain will hold its second annual awards ceremony on 20 March at the Curzon Mayfair cinema in London, with all directing nominations being presented by actor Michael Gambon.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The UK Directors Guild has announced its nominees for the 20th International Director's Guild Awards, which will take place on March 20 at the Curzon Mayfair cinema in London. The awards honor directing achievements from across the world, and this year's nominations include Bill Condon for Kinsey, Michael Gondry for Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, Mike Leigh for Vera Drake, and Clint Eastwood and Martin Scorsese, both nominated in the directing category. 

This marks the second year for the awards, which celebrate outstanding achievements in film direction, with this year's nominations up against some of the best British films, including Vera Drake, The Aviator, and Dead Man's Shoes. Additionally, Leigh is nominated for the British Film Award, while Eastwood was nominated for both the Directing Prize and Best British Film categories. 

The Awards ceremony will take place on March 20 at the Curzon Mayfair cinema in London.

Last year's Oscar winners, Scorsese (The Aviator) and Eastwood (Million Dollar Baby), are again in contention. Other notable nominees are Bill Condon for Kinsey, Michel Gondry for Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, Mike Leigh for Vera Drake, and British filmmakers Shane Meadows, Roger Michell, Pawel Pawlikowski, Pedro Almodovar, and Wong Kar-Wai.

In TV categories, Early Doors and The Alan Clark Diaries vie for best 30-minute show, while Shameless, Hustle, Bodies, Omagh, and Sex Traffic are nominated for 60-minute series. Sam Mendes will receive a lifetime achievement award for his film and theatre work, and Simon McBurney will be honored with an award for outstanding directorial achievement in theatre.
